title: 107_hr3922
content: The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" prevents corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The definition of "domestic" for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code is clarified, stating that they must be created or organized in the United States or under U.S. law, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. In corporate expatriation transactions, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation when it acquires substantially all properties of a nominally foreign corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation when it acquires substantially all properties of a nominally foreign corporation. This occurs when more than 80 percent of the stock of the acquiring corporation is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In certain cases, a lower stock ownership requirement of 50 percent may apply to a nominally foreign corporation if it lacks substantial business activities in the foreign country where it is created or organized. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' includes transactions where a nominally foreign corporation acquires another entity. The text chunk discusses a scenario where a foreign corporation acquires properties of a domestic partnership, and after the transaction, more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former partners of the partnership. The acquiring corporation's stock is held by former partners of the domestic partnership, meeting specific requirements for the transaction. Special rules apply, treating related transactions as one. Special rules apply to related transactions, treating them as one. Stock held by members of the acquiring corporation's affiliated group is not considered in ownership determination. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' refers to a corporation that would be considered foreign if not for certain conditions. The 'expanded affiliated group' is defined as an affiliated group without specific exclusions. The Secretary of the Treasury can adjust corporate tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary of the Treasury can adjust corporate tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code to result in a net decrease in revenues equal to any increase from the amendment. Rates are based on estimates and adjusted for future years as needed. Effective dates for the amendment are specified. The amendment to adjust corporate tax rates applies to expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions before that date for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
